title: FirstFT: Today's top stories
text:
Joe Biden declared it “time to end America's longest war” as he confirmed US troops would withdraw from Afghanistan before the 20th anniversary of the September 11 attacks on New York and the Pentagon.

In two decades of war against Afghan and foreign militants, 2,488 Americans have died and 20,722 have been wounded.

The number of US troops peaked at more than 100,000 in 2010 after the Barack Obama ordered “surge” before falling back. There are currently 2,500 US troops in the country, who will begin to leave on the deadline agreed by previous president Donald Trump of May 1.

Biden was an ardent supporter of withdrawing American troops from Afghanistan when he was vice-president and opposed the escalation ordered by Obama — and backed by US military chiefs — in favour of a counter-terrorism strategy.

“War in Afghanistan was never meant to be a multigenerational undertaking,” Biden said on Wednesday.

What are the prospects for peace in Afghanistan? The Director of National Intelligence wrote in a report this week that they are “low”.

“The Taliban is likely to make gains on the battlefield and the Afghan government will struggle to hold the Taliban at bay if the coalition withdraws support,” the report said. (FT)

Biden's announcement signals a break from the past, writes our US foreign policy and defence correspondent Katrina Manson.

Coronavirus digest

  • Activist hedge fund Elliott Management has built a multibillion-pound stake in GSK after the UK drugmaker underperformed peers and lagged behind in the race to develop a Covid-19 vaccine. 

  • Johnson & Johnson's vaccine pause will last another week after members of a government advisory committee said they did not have enough information to change their advice.

  • The UK has moved closer to making Covid-19 vaccinations compulsory for care workers in England.

  • Leaving the middle seat free on aircraft could help cut the risk of exposure by more than 50 per cent, according to the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

  • India's Covid-19 cases hit a record on Wednesday ahead of Mumbai's lockdown.

  • A group of 175 former world leaders and Nobel laureates urged the US to suspend vaccine patents to boost global inoculation rates. (FT, Reuters)

Covid-19 vaccines show governments can be forces for good, writes Gillian Tett. Sign up for our Coronavirus Business Update email newsletter, delivered three times a week and follow the latest news on our live blog.

In the news

BofA's quarterly net income more than doubles Bank of America more than doubled net income in the first quarter, comfortably beating forecasts as it booked a $1.9bn gain on the improving outlook for loan losses and enjoyed a 62 per cent rise in investment banking fees. Citigroup will also publish results today.

  • JPMorgan Chase, Goldman Sachs and Wells Fargo reported higher than expected profits on Wednesday, fuelled by breakneck growth in investment banking fees, buoyant capital markets and lower credit costs due to an improving economy. (FT)

Coinbase valued at $76bn Investors valued Coinbase at $75.9bn on its Nasdaq debut on Wednesday, the first listing of a leading cryptocurrency exchange and a moment of validation for the digital asset class some 12 years after the creation of bitcoin. (FT)

Hedge funds enjoy best start to year since 2006 After navigating the GameStop short squeeze and collapse of family office Archegos Capital, hedge funds generated returns of 4.8 per cent in the first three months of the year, according to data group Eurekahedge — the best first quarter since 2006. (FT)

Dell to get $10bn dividend in VMware spin-off Shares in Dell Technologies jumped 9 per cent in after-market trading on Wednesday after the US computer maker said it would receive a cash dividend of nearly $10bn in connection with the spin-off of its stake in VMware, easing pressure on its balance sheet. (FT)

Facebook faces leak investigation The social media network is under investigation for a possible breach of EU privacy laws, the Irish Data Protection Commission said on Wednesday. The announcement follows reports of a large-scale data leak in which the personal information of 533m users was shared online. (FT)

Ex-officer who fatally shot Daunte Wright to face manslaughter charge Kim Potter, the former police officer who shot and killed a young black man in a Minneapolis suburb at the weekend, was charged with second-degree manslaughter, a prosecutor said. (FT)

Corporate America pledges to fight efforts to restrict voting Hundreds of the biggest US companies including Amazon, Apple, BlackRock and Goldman Sachs along with top executives and leading law firms have pledged to fight state efforts to restrict voting rights. (FT)

Rouble slips as Moscow braces for new US sanctions Russia assets sold off on Thursday after reports that US president Joe Biden was set to announce a fresh round of sanctions against Moscow, potentially targeting the country's sovereign debt. (FT)

  • Joe Biden, who this week agreed to hold a summit with Russian president Vladimir Putin, is striking a balance between democratic values and pragmatic engagement, writes Philip Stephens.

Bernard Madoff dies The investment manager who orchestrated the largest Ponzi scheme in history has died aged 82 at a federal prison in North Carolina where he was serving a 150-year sentence after pleading guilty in 2009. In 2011, Madoff spoke to the FT from behind bars. Here are three lessons for investors from Madoff's scheme. (FT)

The day ahead

IPO Shares in AppLovin are due to begin trading on the Nasdaq exchange today after the mobile ad tech company and video game publisher raised $1.8bn in an initial public offering. (FT)

Economic data Investors will learn whether another round of stimulus payments that reached US households in March sent sales jumping after falls in February. US industrial production is also set to bounce back for March. (FT, WSJ)

What else we're reading

Nuclear talks intensify Tehran power struggle Iran has weathered the most extensive sanctions in its history, costing the economy at least $200bn. But the regime has been emboldened by surviving the pressure of Donald Trump's policy, with hardliners seeking to ram home the political advantage over their reformist rivals. (FT)

How Jack Ma fell foul of Xi Jinping China's most outspoken billionaire has gone silent. Since Chinese president Xi Jinping unexpectedly called off the blockbuster public offering of Ant Group, Ma's payments and lending business, five months ago, the Alibaba founder has made a single public appearance. Here's how he fell from grace.

Investors braced for momentum and value to collide The strength of the recent rally in cheap stocks could trigger a rare shift in equity market dynamics that some investors expect will fuel the gains of financial and energy companies. (FT)

Johnson's strategy to save the Union Whether you call Boris Johnson's strategy for dealing with the existential aftershocks of Brexit muddling through or the more muscular “toughing it out”, it is underrated as a political approach. The future of the UK may depend on him being right, writes Robert Shrimsley. (FT)

Hong Kong crackdown reaches the classroom Beijing is extending its crackdown on the city's pro-democracy movement into schools with a curriculum that will force teachers to warn students against “subversion” and “foreign interference”. The FT spoke to more than a dozen teachers, parents and administrators about their fears that the national security law will establish wholesale censorship. (FT)

Podcast of the day

Britain's unhealthy legacy of empire Gideon Rachman talks to Sathnam Sanghera about his book Empireland and the legacy of racism and nostalgia that Britain has yet to come to terms with. (FT)
